text:
Hi, I’m Jake Burns, Enterprise
Strategist with AWS.

In this video series, we’re
going to discuss how CTOs can

use the cloud to help their
organizations adapt to customer

needs and deliver enhanced
user experiences through
the use of scalable and cost-effective
technology solutions.
First, let’s talk about culture.

One of the goals of an effective
technology strategy is to drive

product and process innovation
by developing a culture of innovation
and continual improvement.

This can be accomplished
by rewarding, rather than punishing,
calculated risk taking, by offering incentives

to individuals and teams that
take risks and achieve positive
results

using bonuses,
promotions, or other forms
of recognition.

The fact is that risk is a necessary
component of progress.

And in order to innovate, we must
be able to take calculated
risks and experiment.

But, most experiments
fail.

And most experiments
should fail.

Because if you know in advance
it’s going to work, then it isn’t
really an experiment.

It’s important to realize
that failure is not the goal.

Continual improvement
is the goal.

Failure is just an inevitable
side-effect of experimentation,

and experimentation,
along with learning, is what’s

necessary to truly innovate
at scale.

Almost all organizations
embrace the idea of innovation,

but most aren’t willing to suffer
the failed experiments
needed to get there.

And we can’t fault these organizations
for being so cautious.

They need to be cautious,
because within their organizations,

the cost of failure, in terms
of time, effort, and money,

is simply too high to support a culture
of continual experimentation
and innovation.

Simply wanting to experiment
more, or just saying we want
to experiment more, isn’t enough.

We need to first lower the cost
of failure so that our people are

able to experiment freely
without our organizations

having to pay such a high price
for all the experiments
that will inevitably fail.
By incentivizing experimentation,
combined with reducing the cost of failure, our organizations

are able to support a culture
of experimentation
in the long term.

In the cloud is one of the most
powerful ways you can reduce

the cost of failure because
it gives you instant access

to the building blocks you will need
to experiment at low cost.
